      81             : 
      82             : /*
      83             :  * Notifications on workers introduce some lifetime issues. The property we
      84             :  * are trying to satisfy is:
      85             :  *   Whenever a task is dispatched to the main thread to operate on
      86             :  *   a Notification, the Notification should be addrefed on the worker thread
      87             :  *   and a feature should be added to observe the worker lifetime. This main
      88             :  *   thread owner should ensure it properly releases the reference to the
      89             :  *   Notification, additionally removing the feature if necessary.
      90             :  *
      91             :  * To enforce the correct addref and release, along with managing the feature,
      92             :  * we introduce a NotificationRef. Only one object may ever own
      93             :  * a NotificationRef, so UniquePtr<> is used throughout.  The NotificationRef
      94             :  * constructor calls AddRefObject(). When it is destroyed (on any thread) it
      95             :  * releases the Notification on the correct thread.
      96             :  *
      97             :  * Code should only access the underlying Notification object when it can
      98             :  * guarantee that it retains ownership of the NotificationRef while doing so.
      99             :  *
     100             :  * The one kink in this mechanism is that the worker feature may be Notify()ed
     101             :  * if the worker stops running script, even if the Notification's corresponding
     102             :  * UI is still visible to the user. We handle this case with the following
     103             :  * steps:
     104             :  *   a) Close the notification. This is done by blocking the worker on the main
     105             :  *   thread. This ensures that there are no main thread holders when the worker
     106             :  *   resumes. This also deals with the case where Notify() runs on the worker
     107             :  *   before the observer has been created on the main thread. Even in such
     108             :  *   a situation, the CloseNotificationRunnable() will only run after the
     109             :  *   Show task that was previously queued. Since the show task is only queued
     110             :  *   once when the Notification is created, we can be sure that no new tasks
     111             :  *   will follow the Notify().
     112             :  *
     113             :  *   b) Ask the observer to let go of its NotificationRef's underlying
     114             :  *   Notification without proper cleanup since the feature will handle the
     115             :  *   release. This is only OK because every notification has only one
     116             :  *   associated observer. The NotificationRef itself is still owned by the
     117             :  *   observer and deleted by the UniquePtr, but it doesn't do anything since
     118             :  *   the underlying Notification is null.
     119             :  *
     120             :  * To unify code-paths, we use the same NotificationRef in the main
     121             :  * thread implementation too.
     122             :  *
     123             :  * Note that the Notification's JS wrapper does it's standard
     124             :  * AddRef()/Release() and is not affected by any of this.
     125             :  *
     126             :  * Since the worker event queue can have runnables that will dispatch events on
     127             :  * the Notification, the NotificationRef destructor will first try to release
     128             :  * the Notification by dispatching a normal runnable to the worker so that it is
     129             :  * queued after any event runnables. If that dispatch fails, it means the worker
     130             :  * is no longer running and queued WorkerRunnables will be canceled, so we
     131             :  * dispatch a control runnable instead.
     132             :  *
     133             :  */
     134             : class Notification : public DOMEventTargetHelper
